title: Tuesday, 28th February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:01am

AV's daily chat

PM11:01am

You know I haven't got a pic -- cos was too busy dealing with a stupid "Get loans here' spammer

11:01 am
PM11:02am

I thought spam had largely been dealt with by the tech industry

PM11:02am

But it seems to be making a come back

PM11:02am

And phishing attacks

11:02 am
PM11:02am

I'm getting loads currently

PM11:02am

Dunno why people would want to target me

undefined
11:02 am
PM11:02am

Anyway, Bryce

PM11:03am

As well as spam we're also drowning in results

PM11:03am

Drowning

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Just pulling up the statements has made my browser window unusable

PM11:03am

And there are some big moves amongst second liners

PM11:04am

Do we go positive or negative to get us going?

11:04 am
BE11:04am

We can work through the results but it's a wee bit hard to gauge interest among the ROTR.

BE11:05am

I mean, there's not a pot of point in doing ten minutes on aerospace engineers when folk want to talk about buses. Or vice versa, I guess.

BE11:05am

So, we can hold off the RNS onslaught and let the readers express a preference.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

ok

BE11:06am

In the meantime, we can note this Softbank satellite thing.

PM11:06am

OneWeb and Intelsat

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Kleinmanator scoop overnight.

PM11:06am

EXCLUSIVE

BE11:07am

Interesting for a number of reasons, though perhaps not as interesting as the big numbers look.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

The big numbers are mainly big debt numbers, right?

BE11:07am

Yep, and distressed debt at that.

BE11:08am

(@ROTR: we take the time to type the full names of companies on this side of the page. You only get one sentence and still use tickers. Pull your socks up.)

11:08 am
BE11:08am

So, to recap, Oneweb is a low-orbit satellite rig.

BE11:08am

.... into which Softbank's already chucked $1bn as recently as December.

BE11:09am

The idea is to launch a heap -- as in, 700 or so -- wee mini-satellites to provide a quick and cheap way to get capacity up there.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

We can then go into a long and boring look about why more capacity is needed in an industry that's absolutely awash with capacity and in deep deflation at the moment ....

BE11:10am

... but that gets into stuff about Ku and Ka standards, and that's even more boring than the long and boring stuff.

BE11:11am

The upshot is that Softbank's now proposing to buy Intelsat bonds from investors at a little more than half of face value.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Market prices already above Softbank's terms apparently

BE11:11am

What does it mean for the rest of the sector?

BE11:11am

Capacity wise, bad! At least for Eutelsat and SES.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

For Inmarsat, probably nothing. It's niche.

PM11:12am

Isn't everyone in this sector talking about merging with each other all the time?

BE11:13am

Yeah, pretty much. We flagged up the theories around regarding Dish and-or Echostar + Inmarsat in the Saturday FT.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

.... though were largely responsible for Inmsarsat's 14% jump last week, though that's from quite depressed levels.

BE11:13am

Let me chop to some sellside.

PM11:13am

ok

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The flash highlighted by DutchBrat with regards Softbank talking to Inmarsat, SES and Telesat means nearly nothing, incidentally.

PM11:14am

Because they are all talking to each other all the time

BE11:15am

Yup. One assumes talks over commercial relationships with regards spectrum and such, which take a lot of negotiation and a certain amount of co-operation.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The idea of Softbank rolling up the entire sector doesn't make any kind of sense.

BE11:15am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:15am

Softbank's appetite for US companies is showing no signs of abatement. This evening we have seen press reports that Softbank will drive a merger of Intelsat and OneWeb with scant details as to how or why. In this note we try to put some kind of framework around it. As ever with Softbank, this feels like leftfield long term positioning to capture the upside of future big data verticals (especially the connected car).

11:16 am
BE11:16am

What we know: SoftBank has an existing link to OneWeb. It was reported on 19 December 2016 that SoftBank would invest $1.0bn in OneWeb as part of a wider funding $1.2bn round that reportedly included some of the original OneWeb investors. We also know that Intelsat invested $25m in OneWeb as part of a $500m funding round in June 2015- in addition to an unquantified equity stake: Intelsat and OneWeb would collaborate to develop hybrid LEO / GEO end-user terminals; OneWeb committed to develop its platform to provide seamless network interoperability with Intelsat’s Epic (both networks use Ku-band spectrum); Intelsat was granted distribution exclusivity within the aeronautical and maritime verticals and for certain USG and oil and gas applications; and Intelsat was granted certain exclusivity for connected car and rail applications

BE11:16am

A first stab at guessing SoftBank’s intent: SoftBank and its mercurial founder and CEO, Masayoshi Son, has a track record of being visionary. We won’t claim any edge in what his thinking is in driving this merger. Again, what we know is that Intelsat have long been clear that its investment in OneWeb was strategic given: 1. Both companies' fundamental belief in the role of satellite to bridge the digital divide; 2. Both companies' commitment to the Ku-band, and therefore Intelsat has long said OneWeb’s technology is highly complementary to Epic. We’d therefore suggest that SoftBank’s intent is to back an operator with the asset mix to be structurally relevant long-term in the big data verticals of tomorrow (such as the connected car).

BE11:16am

Deal structure: Again, much remains to be learned. The Sky article refers to the deal being conditional upon Intelsat bond-holders accepting being called at sub-par levels (which we note are closely aligned with the current bond prices). This is presumably linked to the idea that any change of control (through an equity investment in Intelsat by SoftBank) would trigger refi clauses for certain of the senior Intelsat bonds. Which in turn would suggest that Softbank would effect an acquisition of Intelsat and then reverse OneWeb into Intelsat through an issue of Intelsat equity. Again, this is all just a guess.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Implications for the others: Reporting from Bloomberg has also suggested that SoftBank has spoken to Telesat, Inmarsat and SES, without any any further details on what the discussions are about. It’s therefore incredibly hard to second guess the implications here. We'd assume, the reference to these other companies is in the context of putting them together with OneWeb. We'd imagine that these discussion were fruitless, not least because: SES (O3b, also a former Greg Wyler business) and Telesat (two prototype HTS-LEO satellites in the Ka-band to be launched in 2017) have non-geostationary roadmaps.

BE11:17am

There's a lot of "huh ..." in that, you'll note.

PM11:17am

This Masayoshi Son really likes his debt

11:17 am
PM11:18am

$120bn of the stuff at a recent count

BE11:18am

Hm. RBC is rather more convinced that he knows what it's doing.

BE11:18am

We believe a move by OneWeb, backed by SoftBank, to effectively reverse itself into Intelsat is very credible. We do not believe OneWeb is interested in acquiring other operators.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

1) Inter-operability: As we detailed in our Jan 25th note BirdWatch - The Sword of Damocles, OneWeb is designed to be inter-operable with Intelsat. Intelsat was a seed investor in OneWeb and uses similar Ku (not Ka) frequencies. Co-operation with Intelsat is an integral part of its design.
2) Boot-strapping One Web: We believe a combination of OneWeb/Intelsat would accelerate OneWeb's development: (a) Intelsat has one of the world's largest terrestrial ground networks - this would allow OneWeb to control its LEO satellites from existing Intelsat control rooms (a massive cost saving) and to use their critical established gateways (the essential satellite-earth backhaul links); and (b) OneWeb would also get access to Intelsat's vast technical resources to accelerate development.
3) LEO/GEO: SES has been at pains to explain the advantage of running a hybrid MEO/GEO fleet saying that a combined fleet works well from a commercial and technical perspective (SES owns O3b, a Medium Earth Orbit (MEO) system).
4) Re-capitalises Intelsat: Any OneWeb-Intelsat deal is likely to see Intelsat be recapitalised. A deal would need approval from Intelsat's equity and credit investors. In our view, one route SoftBank could take is to inject capital, via OneWeb, into Intelsat. This would be similar to SoftBank's acquisition of Sprint, which saw it inject cash in return for new shares. If Intelsat were to issue fresh equity to OneWeb/SoftBank, existing equity shareholders would be diluted but would then hold shares in a business not in serious financial distress and would allow Intelsat to restructure its debt. SoftBank has been raising significant funds including up to $45bn from Saudi Arabia to see a $100bn technology fund.

BE11:18am

merger of OneWeb/Intelsat would be very negative for the other satellite operators as it could herald further significant capacity increases, and consequently lower prices for data. This would affect all operators, including primarily video-centric FSS operators such as Eutelsat and SES due to the impact on its data business, which is magnified by the operational and financial gearing impact. We continue to believe Inmarsat could be the subject of M&A talk, in particular from Echostar, as detailed in our note last year.

BE11:19am

By the way, do check in on Masayoshi's speech to the Mobile World thingmy yesterday.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

He did his singularity routine.

PM11:20am

Omg smile

BE11:20am

http://blogs.barro...ngularity-is-real/

11:20 am
BE11:20am

“I calculated 20 years ago that [The Singularity] would be 2018” when the cross-over happens, he told the packed auditorium. “I recently rechecked the calculation and it was still 2018. If it’s off by a year or two, I don’t care.”

“I believe it’s coming, in the next thirty years, so that’s why I’m in a hurry,” he said, “to bring the cash.”

BE11:21am

Thumbs up

BE11:21am

'Kay.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

So this is the idea that machines will definitely be smarter than humans

BE11:22am

... um, I'm not sure we should head into singularity theory in the format of a live market chat. Let's just say "kinda," and move on to buses and aerospace engineers.

undefined
11:22 am
PM11:22am

Actually -- just quickly on Avanti

PM11:22am

Are they effected by all this?

PM11:22am

Oh, i see they have figs out:

11:22 am
PM11:22am

http://www.investe...1702280700169944X/

BE11:23am

I've lost track of where the Avanti story stands. I'd assume more capacity is bad, and the effective rescue of a distressed competitor is worse. But what do I know?

PM11:23am

So they've increased capacity by 20%, while utilisation is at circa 35%

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Thats the story across the sector

PM11:23am

Bemusing really

PM11:24am

That singularity stuff better hurry up and happen

11:23 am
undefined
BE11:24am

(@Blue horseshoe: haven't heard that.)

BE11:25am

Taylor Wimpey winning on the right, with two requests!

11:24 am
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 179.46, up 1.06 (+0.60%), High: 180.10, Low: 175.80, Volume: 9.39m
BE11:25am

That 0.6% jump really catching the attention of the readership.

PM11:25am

hehe

11:25 am
PM11:25am

http://www.investe...1702280700149920X/

BE11:26am

So, it's fine. It's in line.

BE11:26am

PBT slightly better but it's mostly due to Spain, not UK.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Outlook burdened with loads of stuff about medium term strategy but not a lot on current trading.

BE11:27am

No change to the divi outlook.

BE11:28am

But why am I typing when Canaccord can summarise?

11:28 am
PM11:28am

(thanks Residual)

BE11:28am

Results are all very solid with a c.+2% at the PBT level, which came in at £733m versus our forecast of £720m. The group saw a good performance in 2016 with completions up by c.+5%, ASP up by +10% and operating margins modestly up to 20.8%; all as previously guided. The group has made good progress towards its financial targets as set out in May 2016 and reiterated them today. It is fully committed to paying its ordinary and special dividend of 13.8p per share for 2017, as set out in May 2016. The striking number in the release is the private sales rate for the year to date, which at 0.91 (2016:0.77) is very strong and better than what peers have pointed to recently. While guidance for 2017 has not changed materially, it looks to us that consensus for 2017 will be very well supported with mid-single-digit percentage growth in PBT looking likely for 2017, given the good macro signs recently and particularly strong start to the year. The shares offer a dividend yield of over 7.7% and the group looks well set to pay its dividend commitments and maintain a good ordinary dividend through the cycle. The dividend yield looks attractive relative to the sector, in our view.

BE11:28am

Results summary

UK completions for 2016 were 13,808 (+4.5%) and the average selling price increased by c.+11% to £255k, boosted by mix effects.

Operating profit margins came in at 20.8% (20.3% in 2015), as previously guided, a 50bps improvement.

2016 PBT of £733m was c.+2% ahead of our forecast of £720m.

Net cash of £365m was in line with the net assets per share increasing by +6% to 88.6p. This was after acquiring 6,355 plots with the land bank at c.76k plots at the year end.

Comments around meeting medium-term targets (average margins of 22% and RONA of 30%) are reassuring and management remains confident of its ability to pay significant dividends through the cycle.

Sales rates for the year to date show a very strong start to the year: private sales rate has been 0.91 versus 0.77 last year. Forward order book at £1,978m is strong and means the group is 49% forward sold for 2017. Build costs expected to be up c.+3-4% in 2017. While the 2017 outlook does not seem to have changed materially, the strong start to the year is clearly encouraging.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

aluation

Shares reside on a 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.1.85 times versus the sector average of c.1.75 times and offer a committed dividend yield of c.+7.7% versus the sector average of 6.5%.

PM11:29am

Helluva divi

BE11:29am

Which is why we're prepared to overlook that 1.85 book value, which is a hella lot to pay for a housebuilder.

11:29 am
PM11:29am

hmm

BE11:30am

That view's in the minority though. Here's Codling at Jefferies.

BE11:30am

In our view, when it comes to UK housebuilders, land is King and Taylor Wimpey not only holds all four kings it also holds the majority of
the court cards, a hand even better than a full house. Almost two thirds of the short term landbank was strategically sourced and the average plot cost is 15.4% of the selling price. The short term landbank is supported by a strategic pipeline of some 108,000 plots. In our view and bearing in mind UK housebuilding was, is, and will continue to be a cyclical industry Taylor Wimpey's landbank provides it more flexibility than any other housebuilder we follow to manage the cyclical twists and turns. The Redfern Review was bolder and more ambitious than the Government’s own White Paper, both suggested the answer to the UK housing crisis was to build more houses, but the Redfern Review suggested the solution was to be found in a long term framework rather than working within electoral cycles.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

Blimey that's pretty frothy

BE11:30am

Hm.

undefined
11:31 am
PM11:31am

Go-Ahead going backwards

PM11:31am

Quickly

Go-Ahead Group PLC (GOG:LSE): Last: 1,964, down 320.9 (-14.04%), High: 1,991, Low: 1,915, Volume: 232.49k
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Warning.

PM11:31am

Warning yeah

BE11:32am

Slowdown in passenger volumes in Regional Bus.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Interims here http://www.investe...1702280700159929X/

BE11:32am

Costs up, cost cutting delayed.

BE11:33am

Govia Thameslink Railway causing problems. But we knew that already.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Investec seem to have forgotten to send me their downgrade this morning, so here's Deutsche Bank instead.

BE11:34am

Go-Ahead has today warned on June-17 expectations. Management has flagged weakness in both the Regional Bus business and further risk in the GTR rail franchise. Our preliminary estimate is that FY17 Group EBITA consensus forecasts may fall around 9% and that there will be knock-on impacts for FY18+ forecasts given the ongoing nature of weak bus passenger volumes and further GTR uncertainty. In our view the commentary on Deregulated Bus will also weigh on the other bus stocks in the sector.

BE11:34am

Management has said “Our expectations for full year regional bus division profitability have lowered as a result of the slowdown in passenger volumes across the business, most notably in the north east and Oxford.” We already forecast Deregulated Bus EBITA down £1m yoy in FY17 to £49m but clearly management commentary suggests that known existing weakness in industry volumes is not alleviating. In our view consensus consolidated Bus EBITA will fall from c£98m to DBE of £94m.

11:34 am
PM11:35am

It seems management have been difficult to get hold of this morning

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:35am

That's martin Brown at Shore

11:35 am
PM11:35am

And he's a buyer. Or was

BE11:35am

Can't blame them avoiding having some hack at the Evening Standard berate you for Southern.

BE11:36am

Back to DB's new numbers. One moment.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Go-Ahead’s GTR rail franchise (London Bridge & Southern) is known to have major problems. Management has already downgraded guidance in the past as a result. Today’s commentary indicates no more certainty: “the long-running industrial relations issues in GTR have introduced additional costs and delays to expected efficiencies which will result in lower than anticipated profits in the full
year... management’s judgement of these outcomes is that, relating to events up
to 31 December 2016, the impact on rail profitability is likely to be within a range of plus or minus £10m. Given the ontinuing uncertainty, our expectation for the full year is that this range will increase to plus or minus £15m.”

BE11:36am

We forecast FY17 Rail EBITA of £67m so the +- £15m is material in percentage terms. In our view the +- £15m will have a mid-point of c£60m. Given the uncertainty, we suspect the market may move towards the bottom end of the £45m - £75m range. The eventual outturn will depend on (a) whether reliability of services improve and (b) the outcome of management’s
negotiations with the Department for Transport. We believe that the bottom end of the range assumes operational performance doesn’t improve and management reaches an outcome with the DfT towards the lower end of its expectations.

BE11:36am

Our preliminary calculation is that assuming a cut of say £5m in Regional Bus
and £10m in UK Rail we get to a £15m cut to consensus. Consensus currently forecasts FY17 Group EBITA of c£161m so this would in theory be a 9% cut.

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Cheers for that

undefined
PM11:37am

Meggitt on a run

11:37 am
Meggitt PLC (MGGT:LSE): Last: 465.90, up 49.8 (+11.97%), High: 466.20, Low: 440.00, Volume: 2.42m
PM11:37am

My bid story around this fade away pretty quickly

PM11:38am

But actual trading surprised to the upside

11:38 am
PM11:38am

http://www.investe...1702280700089743X/

BE11:38am

It's a smallish beat, yes.

BE11:38am

And a reassuring outlook.

11:38 am
PM11:39am

Plus a divi hike

BE11:39am

And a bit of finagling about IFRS15, because it's aerospace.

BE11:39am

Who've we not quoted in the result onslaught? UBS?

11:39 am
BE11:40am

2016 results were better than expected. Meggitt reported FY16 group revenues of £1,992m (up 1% y/y organically, UBSe £1,953m, Cons £1,919m), Meggitt reported FY16 group operating profit of £379.7m (2% above UBSe £373m). Underlying PBT was €352m, 3% ahead of Cons £341m and UBSe £340m. The beat vs. our numbers was mainly driven by Sensing Systems and Controls. Underlying EPS came in at 34.8p vs. cons 34.2p. FCF came in stronger than expected £131m vs. cons £102m (UBSe £104m) driven by lower capex (phasing) and good working capital, with net debt/EBITDA at 2.1x. 2017 guidance is broadly aligned with our expectations. Mainly on the back of MPS, Meggitt expects a 200-250 bps net operating margin improvement by 2021. This compares with our expectation of 200bps margin improvement for the group by 2021 (post 120bps (UBSe) headwind from IFRS 15).

BE11:40am

4 civil aftermarket growth came in at 4.5pct (4Q16 had 5 trading days less than 4Q15). R&D capitalised and programme participation costs came in aligned with previous guidance. Meggitt reported divisional operating profit: Aircraft Braking Systems £146.6m (UBSe £148m), Control Systems £117.6m (UBSe £104m), Polymers and Composites £39.5m (UBSe £42m), Sensing Systems £73m (UBSe £63m) and Equipment Group £3m (UBSe £15m).

BE11:40am

In 2017 the group expects 2%-4% organic revenue growth vs UBSe organic sales growth of 3.6%. 2017 guidance is for civil OE revenues up 6%-8% organically, civil AM 4%-6% (UBSe 4.5%), military revenues to grow 1%-3%, energy revenues to decline 5%-10%. 2017 operating margins are expected to be flat to up 30bps vs. UBSe 30 bps improvement. By 2021 Meggitt also expects a £200m of incremental cash from improved inventory turns.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

So ........ bounce.

BE11:41am

Barclays spells out why.

BE11:41am

Meggitt has been unfairly dragged down by recent turbulence at Cobham, in our view. Today’s modest earnings beat and strong cash beat leaves the balance sheet at 2.1x ND/EBITDA vs. covenants at 3.5x, which should allay investor concerns with regard to BS risk.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The H2’16 results saw a modest beat across the board; Group revenues of £1110m, +7% vs. co cons, adj. PBT £200m +6% vs. cons, FCF £165m +22% vs. cons. Civil AM in FY16 was +5% organic. “2016 trading was very much in line with our expectations and the stronger second half performance gives us good momentum going into 2017”. The company expects 2% to 4% organic growth in FY17 (with Civil AM expected to be in the 4% to 6% range, with Civil OE between 6% and 8%. The company remains ‘cautious’ in FY17 for defence and expects further organic declines in Energy. Overall group margins are expected to remain flat to +30bps higher, again in-line with expectations.

Valuation on FY18E of just 10.4x P/E, 9x EV/EBITDA for a 6.6% FCF yield and ~4% divi, the shares offer good value, in our view.

BE11:41am

10x 2018?! ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, Hm.

undefined
11:42 am
BE11:42am

We could stay in the sector. There's GKN and Babcock as well.

BE11:42am

But perhaps a break from results is in order.

BE11:43am

There's BT, for instance.

11:43 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 329.45, down 1.35 (-0.41%), High: 329.55, Low: 326.50, Volume: 5.36m
BE11:43am

Come back a bit from an early selloff ....

BE11:44am

.... which was on the news that Ofcom wants people without the internet to be charged less.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

(I'd suggest they should be charged more. What kind of idyllic life is that?)

PM11:44am

(Note to those on the right: if you type in CAPS the system blocks you. I have to unblock you manually, which i will stop doing if you keep writing in CAPS)

BE11:45am

The earnings hit ............ is probably pretty modest.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Here's Goldman to talk us through the detail.

BE11:45am

As part of its narrowband market review, Ofcom is proposing to cut standalone landline pricing (i.e. line rental currently at £18.99/month) by c.£5-7/month and restrict further increases to ‘in line with inflation’. Ofcom has cited this as an area it was looking at as part of the narrowband review, but has now confirmed a specific retail price control, which we view as a modest negative, especially given line rental increases in the UK have been a key driver of fixed line inflation over recent years.

BE11:45am

However, we had not been expecting material further stand-alone price increases in line rental, given recent advertising rule changes, and we note BT’s recent price changes (from March) were focused on broadband bundles not line rental. Overall, on our calculations, this would imply a negative impact on BT FY18 EBITDA by c.1%. Implications
Ofcom has stated that the price cut will apply to all BT customers using stand-alone landline telephony contracts but not for customers who have a bundle, as Ofcom believes this market is delivering good outcomes. Overall, there are currently 2.9mn stand-alone landline consumers in the UK (1.7mn landline only, 1.2mn with broadband who buy landline separately). Of these 2.9mn customers, Ofcom cites that BT has c.80% share, i.e. 2.3mn.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

BT has previously cited that it has 1.0-1.5mn voice-only residential lines, of which roughly a third to a half are already taking a value product (such as Home Phone Saver product/BT Basic service at £5.10/month). This potentially does not include the second bucket of ‘split customers’ as defined by Ofcom. We estimate that, if the full 2.3mn customers were impacted, this would imply a c.£100mn impact for BT (revenue/EBITDA) or c.1/3% of FY18 EBITDA/FCF. Although we note that it is less clear if all of the ‘split customers’ would be impacted; hence, the impact could be restricted to c.£50mn if it were just the c.1m voice-only customers that are not taking a value product.

BE11:46am

And Deutsche.

PM11:46am

This is a great theme Bryce -- I think I'd pay more to be without the web

11:46 am
PM11:46am

But go on

BE11:46am

The regulator suggests that 2.3m customers could see their bills fall though BT flags that just 1.0-1.5m of its consumer base is line-rental only but that likely excludes some split purchase customers and 0.5m SMEs availing of residential tariffs. The mid point of a £5-7 retail line rental price cut is £5 ex VAT which across say 2m customers and (un)taxed, equates to £100m annually (4% off EPS,1.5% off EBITDA and 3% of FCF). Investors will be reminded that the regulatory 'tone' remains that of tightening. Ofcom is pushing ahead remedying what it sees as distortions in the UK Telco market post its 10-year review. Separation of Openreach and wholesale fibre are further areas where we see little sign of regulatory tone becoming more tuneful for BT.

BE11:47am

...... yeah, it's a definite trend.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

You'll have seen Nokia's relaunched 3310.

BE11:47am

https://www.thegua...-it-even-has-snake

BE11:47am

It should be a premium product. Charge £700 a handset.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Aspirational Neo-Luddism.

Telit Communications

PM11:48am

11:48 am

undefined

11:51 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 336.90, up 7.9 (+2.40%), High: 338.90, Low: 334.30, Volume: 3.72m

BE11:53am

Jefferies' latest February 2017 UK consumer survey results indicate consumer
confidence is unsustainable as inflation bites and technology advancements
threaten job security. Meanwhile consumer perceptions show M&S is
consolidating its omni-channel improvements whilst Next continues to lose its
historic advantage. Given this, and M&S' changes in strategy, we upgrade M&S
from Underperform to Buy whilst maintaining Holds on Next and Debenhams.

BE11:54am

UK consumer confidence is unsustainable. The gap between consumers' views of
their own future financial situation and the economy has widened to 30 points and with
only 36% of consumers currently worried about inflation we see accelerating inflation as
the catalyst for a decline in discretionary consumer spending leading us to reduce our sales
forecasts further.
Artificial intelligence continues to be a threat to employment. Our survey results
suggest consumers are too confident about their own job prospects given the concentration
of power by technology led companies. For example the market capitalisation of each FTE
employee at Facebook is $23.5m, $1.4m at Amazon, $110k at M&S and only $40k at Tesco.
Omni-channel retailing is the future. One of the surprising results from our latest
survey is just how much consumers like shopping both in a store and online with a retailer.
45% of multi-channel shoppers at both M&S and Next are highly likely to recommend the
retailer, 2x higher than single channel shoppers and even higher than the 33% of customers
that would highly recommend ASOS, or 31% for Amazon.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

M&S and Debenhams improve customer perceptions whilst Next lags. For the first
time Next's overall net promoter score of 19% (NPS) fell below that of M&S (23%) and
Debenhams (20%) which is a significant change from 18 months ago when Next's NPS was
32%. This reflects consumers' perceptions, and our multi-channel comparison study, that
M&S and Debenhams have significantly closed the gap and in some cases overtaken Next
for the quality of their website content and delivery proposition.
Macro concerns weigh on our earnings estimates. We have cut our FY18E and FY19E
PBT forecasts for Next and Debenhams and lie below consensus by up to 18%. In contrast,
given M&S' strategy plans to cut overseas losses and improve its Clothing sales densities,
and the encouraging survey results, we change our view and raise our forecasts.
M&S upgraded to Buy, Next and Debenhams maintained Hold. M&S is now our
preferred stock to own among the UK clothing retailers. Offering a 6.5% dividend yield and
improving sales momentum we see an opportunity to buy into the five year, admittedly
back end loaded, strategy at an attractive valuation of 11x cal 18 EPS.

BE11:59am

Impact: Dividend in line with share buyback earlier than expected. Near-term outlook subdued but management confident of meeting expectations.
With the majority of numbers already known, the focus on Moneysupermarket today is on capital returns and the current trading outlook. Capital returns surprised us positively but the outlook for the first two months of 2017 is cautious. Questions today will likely focus on how much of the revenue pressure in the first two months of 2017 is cyclical vs structural.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Moneysupermarket had already announced the majority of its key figures in its January 19th pre close statement. The dividend for the year of 9.75p was in line with our expectations. The company chose to announce a share buyback of £40m to be conducted during 2017 which we had not included in our estimates. We believe that this is a positive that the market had not expected, and we had certainly not expected.

BE11:59am

The revenue outlook for the first two months of the year was relatively cautious in our view. Management stated that insurance and the core money business (credit cards and loans) showed strong growth in the first two months of the year. However low interest rates continue to hurt savings and current account switching and Energy has not yet had a collective switch year to date. Management have said that revenues are running behind last year which we believe will be taken negatively. However, at the same time the company is confident of meeting expectations (2017E adjusting operating profit consensus £113m RBC £112.4m).

BE12:00pm

Lack of a collective drags down Jan/Feb: The release states “the Board is confident of delivering its expectations for the year” (cons adj op profit £113m). The group states Jan/Feb revenues were "behind last year". "Strong growth" in "core" Money (credit cards and loans) and Insurance was offset by savings/current accounts (impacted by low interest rates) and Energy which was "lower" as there was no collective in the year thus far. We note Money comps ease from Q2 and still expect one or two collectives later in the year.

BE12:01pm

With the stock having risen +34% over the last 4m and close to our target price we lower to Neutral wanting to see evidence that the group's technology investment will allow the group to raise margins. With new CEO Mark Lewis joining 13th March we expect that in H2 2017 so see few catalysts in the short term.
